docs.lead_paragraph: JOHNNY PESKY walked out of the house yesterday morning and it started all over again. ''Some wise guy gave me a shot,'' Pesky recounted. ''He said, 'They're gonna hold the ball.'''

docs.lead_paragraph: Curt Schilling wheeled his black sport utility vehicle out of the cramped players parking lot at Fenway Park, and several dozen fans perched behind barricades screamed to him. Schilling's name morphed from two syllables into one jumbled screech, something that sounded like Schhiiiinnnggg. Schilling powered the Boston Red Sox past the San Diego Padres Thursday night, providing more evidence that he is now their ace and causing the fans to pulsate. With police approval, Schilling went the wrong way on Yawkey Way, motored ahead, and made a right onto Boylston Street.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox pitcher Curt Schilling has immersed himself in Boston's storied baseball legacy and has ingratiated himself with Boston's notoriously obsessive fans; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Larry Lucchino turns away from his computer and rises from the swivel chair in his office, he is at eye level with a program from the 2003 American League Championship Series. A fan framed it and sent it to Lucchino, the president of the Boston Red Sox, at Fenway Park. Beneath the cover are the scores of each game between the Red Sox and the Yankees, and two words: unfinished business. When Lucchino leaves the office, he may glimpse the front page of The Boston Evening Globe from Sept. 11, 1918, the last time business really was finished at Fenway. A framed copy proclaiming the last Red Sox championship hangs alone on a wall opposite the lobby receptionist. ''No more than 15,000 persons were on hand,'' the article begins, and the play-by-play shows that Red Sox left fielder Babe Ruth caught the second-to-last out.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox have spent past few years and this offseason preparing to win elusive championship, trying to eradicate history of finishing second in their division for six consecutive years; management has made sweeping changes, from expansion of seating capacity at Fenway Park to look of roster to scouting methods; photos (L)

headline.main: Red Sox Trying to Picture the Parade

docs.lead_paragraph: The Boston Red Sox signed a high-profile player Saturday, but it was not the much-discussed and much-dissected addition of shortstop Alex Rodriguez from the Texas Rangers. Instead, the Red Sox addressed a glaring need by signing the free-agent closer Keith Foulke to a three-year contract with an option that The Associated Press said guaranteed him $24 million. General Manager Theo Epstein said the Red Sox planned to use Foulke as ''a weapon'' out of the bullpen and would not simply use him for one-inning saves in the ninth inning.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox sign pitcher Keith Foulke to three-year contract (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Boston Red Sox feature some prominent first names: Manny. Nomar. Pedro. Bill. Bill? Fine, so maybe a surname is required in this case. Third baseman Bill Mueller is no superstar. But he is no longer unknown. A batting championship will do that every time.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox third baseman Bill Mueller's unexpected .326 batting average this season earned him American League batting championship (M)

headline.main: Mueller Has Fans Rooting In Dugout

docs.lead_paragraph: The Boston Red Sox will hire Bill James, the writer and statistical expert, as a senior adviser, Theo Epstein, their assistant general manager, said yesterday. James attracted wide respect in the 1980's for his annual book, ''The Bill James Baseball Abstract,'' which analyzed the game with easily understood but unconventional statistics in an attempt to quantify players' contributions to their teams. (AP) PHILLIES WILL WOO THOME: A tour of the new stadium site, a hockey game and maybe even a cheesesteak. The free-agent slugger Jim Thome will receive red-carpet treatment when he meets with the Phillies today. Thome, who hit a club-record 52 homers last season for the Cleveland Indians, is the most coveted hitter in this winter's free-agent market. MARINERS' MARTINEZ IN LIMBO: The Mariners decided to decline their one-year option on designated hitter Edgar Martinez, leaving the immediate future unclear for one of the team's most popular players. The Mariners had a $10 million option and had to decide by midnight last night whether to use it.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox hire baseball statistician Bill James as senior adviser (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: On Sept. 28, 1960, after Ted Williams delivered his last hit for the Boston Red Sox, a home run into the bullpen, he circled the bases with his head down and refused the pleas of his adoring fans and teammates to appear on the dugout steps for one final wave. As John Updike later explained in The New Yorker, ''Gods do not answer letters.'' Williams, who died yesterday at 83, could be an ornery man, carrying grudges as he carried a baseball bat: determinedly. Yet what he will most be remembered for was his talent for striking a baseball, a man who understood what he called the ''science'' of hitting perhaps better than anyone, who combined endless practice, preternatural eyesight and a laser-like focus on every pitch that came his way to set the record books on fire.
docs.abstract: Editorial tribute to former Boston Red Sox slugger Ted Williams, who has died at age 83

docs.lead_paragraph: UNDER a friendly sky here a few weeks back, David R. Mellor toed the third-base line in Fenway Park, calling instructions to a man pushing a heavy iron roller. ''Go over the heel one more time,'' Mr. Mellor instructed, ''and then you're done.'' It was a brilliant summer morning, the stadium empty, the sun chasing the aroma of sorrow and heartache that has hung over this field since 1919, when the Red Sox sold Babe Ruth to the New York Yankees. Mr. Mellor, the director of grounds at Fenway, paused to admire his crew's work.
docs.abstract: Article profiles David Mellor, professional groundskeeper and director of grounds for Boston Red Sox at Fenway Park, who creates lawns with grass in variety of stripes, plaids, wavy squiggles and checkerboards; also works on minor league fields; photos (M)
